A costly risk assessment failure  

 

In 2014, a scaffolding company was ordered to pay $752,000 in damages to an employee who injured his leg while lifting and carrying heavy scaffolding components.

 

The injured employee, Paul Rankin, was employed on a casual basis. Rankin was injured during a period of unsupervised activity at a worksite, after dropping a heavy object against his shin and ankle.

 

The court determined that the scaffolding company failed to create and maintain a safe system of work by requiring its employees to lift and move heavy objects, and that a thorough risk assessment would have avoided the injury.

 

Risk management involves the following four steps:

Managing WHS risks is an ongoing process that is triggered by any changes to your work activities. Therefore, anyone with risk management duties should go through these four steps when they start a business, if they change workplaces or work practices, if they introduce new equipment or structures or if any other event creates a possible risk associated with the business or undertaking.

Step 1: Identify hazards – consider what in the workplace could cause harm to health and safety.

Step 2: Assess risks – understand the nature and seriousness of the possible harm and the probability of it occurring.

Step 3: Control risks – implement the most effective and reasonably practicable measures to control the risks.

Step 4: Review control measures – ensure the safety measures are working as planned.
